description: My Khe Beach is a stunning 9-kilometer stretch of pristine coastline along Da Nang's eastern shore, recognized by Forbes Magazine in 2005 as one of the six most attractive beaches on the planet. Located just 3 kilometers from Da Nang's city center and easily accessible from the international airport in 15 minutes, this beach perfectly balances urban convenience with tranquil seaside escape. The beach features fine white sand, clear blue waters, and gentle waves that have made it Vietnam's premier coastal destination. During the Vietnam War, American soldiers nicknamed it "China Beach" and used it as a rest and recuperation center, where up to 75,000 troops would surf, swim, and unwind between missions. This wartime legacy inspired a 61-episode American television series that aired from 1988 to 1991. Today, My Khe has transformed into an internationally recognized beach destination that meets global standards for safety, environment, and quality. The beach is flanked by luxury resorts, beachfront cafes, and fresh seafood restaurants along Vo Nguyen Giap Street, while the nearby Son Tra Peninsula offers limestone caves, panoramic viewpoints, and the famous Lady Buddha statue. What sets My Khe apart is its dual identity: a peaceful natural paradise at sunrise when locals practice Tai Chi and watch fishing boats return, and a vibrant activity hub during the day with water sports, sunbathing, and beachside dining.
highlights: The beach stretches for 9 kilometers along Da Nang's coast with consistently fine white sand and clear blue waters that earned Forbes Magazine recognition in 2005 as one of the six most attractive beaches on the planet.

During the Vietnam War, the beach served as the official R&R center for 75,000 American troops stationed at the Da Nang military base, where the China Beach Surf Club became a legendary surfing spot and symbol of wartime camaraderie.

The beach faces directly east, creating spectacular sunrise views over the South China Sea with fishing boats dotting the horizon, attracting hundreds of locals each morning for exercise classes, ocean swims, and Tai Chi practice between 5 AM and 7 AM.

Lifeguard-monitored swimming zones with safety flags operate daily from 5 AM to 8 PM during the dry season (February to August), when temperatures reach 25-35Â°C and seas are calm and ideal for swimming.
The surf season runs from September to March with consistent waves created by offshore winds, while April to July offers perfect conditions for beginner surfers with gentler swells.

Multiple sections of the beach offer sun lounger rentals for approximately 40,000 VND per day, with beachside bars and vendors selling fresh smoothies, cold drinks, and local snacks within steps of the water.
The nearby Son Tra Peninsula, just 15 minutes away, features hidden limestone caves, pagodas, forest trails, wild monkeys, and the towering Lady Buddha statue with panoramic coastal views.

Vo Nguyen Giap Street runs parallel to the entire beach, lined with Michelin-recognized seafood restaurants like Be Ni 2 and 4U Seafood Restaurant, where diners select live catches from tanks to be prepared on the spot.

Water sports facilities offer parasailing for 500,000-800,000 VND (15-20 minutes airtime), jet skiing for 500,000-900,000 VND per ride (10-30 minutes), and surfboard rentals from 200,000-400,000 VND with private lessons available.
The beach remains free to access with no entry fees, maintaining its local character while offering international-standard facilities and remaining only minutes from Da Nang's bustling downtown area.
tips: Visit between 5 AM and 7 AM to experience the magical local sunrise culture when hundreds of Vietnamese residents gather for morning exercises, Tai Chi, and ocean swims while fishing boats return to shore - the beach becomes surprisingly quiet just hours later.

Book accommodation and water sports in advance if visiting during peak season from April to September when the beach is busiest and prices are higher, but avoid October to December when monsoon rains create rough seas and murky water unsuitable for swimming.
Access the beach at Pham Van Dong Park, the most popular entry point with changing rooms, sunbed rentals, lifeguards, and easy parking, located along Vo Nguyen Giap Street.
Rent sun loungers early in the day for 40,000 VND (less than $2) for all-day use, as natural shade from palm trees is limited and midday sun becomes uncomfortably hot without cover.
Swim only in designated flagged zones with lifeguards on duty, especially during summer months when jellyfish are more common in the waters.

Try the Michelin-recognized seafood restaurants along Vo Nguyen Giap Street like Be Ni 2 or 4U Seafood Restaurant where you select live seafood from tanks - a seafood hot pot for two costs around $10, far less than resort dining.
Bring your own towel or beach mat as sunbeds aren't always available in all sections, and many areas remain free to access without rental requirements.
Cover up with regular clothes when leaving the beach to walk along public streets or enter restaurants, as Vietnamese culture expects modest dress outside the sand.
Combine your beach visit with a trip to Son Tra Peninsula 15 minutes away to see the Lady Buddha statue, hidden caves, and panoramic viewpoints for a full-day itinerary.
Schedule surfing lessons or rentals during the ideal wave season from September to March when offshore winds create the best conditions, with private two-hour lessons costing 1,040,000-1,850,000 VND.
Visit local food outlets directly across the street from the beach where vendors display fresh seafood market-style with significantly lower prices than beachfront restaurants.
Plan to leave before sunset as the beach area quiets down rapidly after dark with limited nightlife - Da Nang's evening entertainment is concentrated in the city center, not along the beach.
vibe: My Khe Beach offers a distinctly peaceful, almost meditative atmosphere that feels worlds away from the typical crowded Asian beach resort, despite being minutes from a major city. The early morning hours transform the beach into a community gathering space where the rhythmic sound of waves mixes with Vietnamese music from exercise classes, the splash of morning swimmers, and the gentle movements of Tai Chi practitioners - it's a window into authentic local life that disappears by mid-morning. During midday, the beach takes on a more international character with tourists swimming in calm, turquoise waters or lounging under umbrellas, yet it never feels overwhelming or overdeveloped. The sand remains remarkably clean and spacious, with enough room that you can always find your own quiet section. Unlike Thailand's party beaches or Bali's vendor-heavy shores, My Khe maintains an understated, almost humble quality - locals avoid the sun during peak hours, so afternoons bring a serene emptiness that's increasingly rare along Asia's coast. Come 4 PM, Vietnamese families and young people flood back, bringing energy and laughter as they play beach games, wade in the shallows, and gather for sunset photos. The beach bars and seafood restaurants create a relaxed social atmosphere rather than a raucous party scene. By evening, as the last rays of sunlight fade, the beach returns to tranquility, with only scattered couples walking the shore and the distant lights of fishing boats on the horizon. It's this rhythm - quiet dawn, peaceful day, gentle evening buzz, early nightfall - that gives My Khe its unique, balanced character between nature and city, past and present.
expectations: Visitors expect My Khe Beach to be a remote, undeveloped tropical paradise far from civilization based on its Forbes recognition and pristine reputation.
Travelers assume the beach will be packed with tourists year-round given its status as one of the world's most beautiful beaches.
Many visitors expect abundant natural shade from palm trees and beach vegetation for escaping the midday sun.
Tourists anticipate vibrant nightlife and beach parties extending into the evening, similar to famous beach destinations in Thailand or Bali.
Visitors often believe the beach will have perfect swimming conditions and calm waters throughout the entire year.
reality: My Khe Beach is actually just 3 kilometers from downtown Da Nang with luxury resorts, restaurants, and cafes lining the shore - it's remarkably accessible with the international airport only 15 minutes away, yet it maintains a peaceful, uncrowded atmosphere.

The beach is surprisingly quiet most of the day because Vietnamese locals actively avoid the sun, so midday and afternoon hours are dominated by tourists - the real crowds appear early morning (5-7 AM) when locals exercise and late afternoon (4 PM onwards) when families return.

While some palm trees have been planted for shade, most of the 9-kilometer beach lacks natural cover, making sun lounger rentals (40,000 VND) essential for midday comfort as the tropical sun becomes uncomfortably intense.

My Khe Beach has virtually no nightlife scene - it becomes remarkably quiet after sunset as most activity shifts to Da Nang's city center, making it primarily a sunrise-to-sunset destination perfect for relaxation rather than evening entertainment.

Swimming conditions vary dramatically by season - the dry months from February to August offer calm, clear waters ideal for swimming, but October to December brings monsoon rains, strong waves, and murky water that make swimming challenging or unsafe despite lifeguards being present.
unique_facts: In 1965, My Khe Beach marked the first official landing site when 3,500 U.S. troops disembarked on its shores, beginning the ground phase of American involvement in the Vietnam War.

The China Beach Surf Club, established by American soldiers in the mid-1960s, became legendary among troops as a rare recreational outlet where soldiers built makeshift surfboards from spare parts and military equipment repair materials.
The beach's Vietnamese name "My Khe" translates to "beautiful stream" or "beautiful river" because a small waterway once flowed through the original fishing village that gave the area its name.

The American television series "China Beach" ran for 61 episodes from 1988 to 1991, focusing on Army nurses and personnel at the Da Nang evacuation hospital, bringing international recognition to the beach decades after the war ended.
Australian magazine Sunday Herald Sun also recognized My Khe as one of the world's top ten Asian beaches, giving it multiple international accolades beyond the famous Forbes recognition.
My Khe Beach is one of only a handful of Vietnamese beaches that meets international standards for safety, environmental quality, and visitor facilities, earning official quality certifications.

Nearly 75,000 American military personnel were stationed at the Da Nang base during the war's peak, with the beach designated as the official U.S. Chief of Staff R&R center for swimming, surfing, and BBQ parties.
The beach remained relatively unknown to international tourists until the early 2000s when Vietnam's tourism industry began expanding, spending most of its history as a quiet local destination.
Every morning, fishing boats return to My Khe Beach shores around sunrise (5-7 AM) to offload fresh seafood catches that are immediately sold at roadside markets across Vo Nguyen Giap Street.
The nearby Son Tra Peninsula creates natural protection for the bay, helping maintain the calm water conditions that make My Khe ideal for swimming during the dry season months.
During the rainy season, particularly in October and November, the beach sometimes suffers from litter issues during peak tourist periods, contrasting with its typically pristine reputation.
Lifeguards at My Khe Beach work daily shifts from 5 AM to approximately 8 PM, maintaining unusually long hours to accommodate both early morning local swimmers and evening beachgoers.
surprises: The most magical beach experience happens at dawn (5-7 AM) when hundreds of Vietnamese locals transform the shore into an outdoor fitness center with exercise classes, synchronized swimming, running groups, and Tai Chi sessions - something guidebooks rarely emphasize.

The beach becomes almost eerily empty during midday hours (10 AM - 3 PM) when Vietnamese sun-avoiders disappear, creating a stark contrast to the crowded mornings and making it feel like a private beach during peak sunshine.
Simple roadside food stalls directly across from the beach offer incredibly fresh seafood at a fraction of resort prices - a full seafood hot pot for two people costs around $10 at these local spots.

Michelin-recognized restaurants like Be Ni 2 and 4U Seafood Restaurant sit casually along the beach road where you select live crabs, lobsters, and fish from tanks and watch them being prepared - fine dining without the formal atmosphere.
The beach offers shockingly affordable water sports with jet ski rides starting at 500,000 VND (around $20) for 15 minutes and full-day sun loungers costing just 40,000 VND (under $2).

Urban convenience meets beach paradise - you can enjoy world-class coffee, massage services, international restaurants, and modern shopping all within a 5-minute walk from the sand, making it feel like a beach neighborhood rather than a resort zone.

The wartime history is largely invisible today except for the continued use of the nickname "China Beach" by some Western visitors - there are no museums, monuments, or obvious reminders of the thousands of American troops who once surfed here.

Vietnamese vendors on the beach are surprisingly low-key compared to other Asian destinations - while some offer massages, snacks, and tours, they're generally respectful and not aggressively persistent.

The beach completely lacks the party atmosphere of famous Asian beaches - by 8 PM, the shoreline is virtually deserted with only scattered couples walking, creating an unexpectedly peaceful evening environment.
Between April and July, the waves are perfect for beginner surfers despite My Khe being known for its calm waters - the beach actually has two distinct personalities depending on the season.
Local beach bars serve excellent Vietnamese coffee, fresh coconuts, and smoothies at incredibly reasonable prices (often under $2) while you lounge steps from the water with full ocean views.

The 9-kilometer beach means you can walk for nearly an hour along pristine sand and still discover new sections with different vibes, restaurants, and activity levels - it's far larger than most visitors realize.
